Automatic differentiation of quantum functions¶

Quantum functions¶

A quantum function (qfunc) is any parameterized function \(f(x;\bm{\theta})\) which can be evaluated on a quantum circuit via the Born rule:

\[f(x; \bm{\theta}) = \langle \hat{B} \rangle = \langle 0 | U^\dagger(x;\bm{\theta})\hat{B}U(x;\bm{\theta}) | 0 \rangle.\]

Here, \(\hat{B}\) is an observable measured at the circuit output and \(| 0 \rangle\) is a fixed initial state (e.g., the vacuum or a spin-down state). Both the input \(x\) and the parameters \(\bm{\theta}\) enter the quantum circuit as arguments used in the gates which are used to build the unitary \(U(x;\bm{\theta})\). For convenience, we can also write the unitary conjugation as a transformation \(\mathcal{C}_U\) acting on the operator \(\hat{B}\):

\[U^\dagger(x;\bm{\theta})\hat{B}U(x;\bm{\theta}) = \mathcal{C}_U(\hat{B}).\]

Note that the measurement operator \(\hat{B}\) has no dependence on the the input \(x\) or the parameters \(\bm{\theta}\).

Gradients of quantum functions¶

If the transformation \(\mathcal{C}_U\) depends smoothly on a parameter \(\theta_i\), then the associated quantum function will have a well-defined gradient:

\[\nabla_{\theta_i}f(x; \bm{\theta}) = \langle 0 | \nabla_{\theta_i}\mathcal{C}_U(\hat{B}) | 0 \rangle \in \mathbb{R}.\]

What does this gradient look like? To answer this, we will have to specify how the full circuit unitary \(U(x;\bm{\theta})\) depends on the specific parameter \(\theta_i\). Like any quantum computation, we can decompose a unitary into an ordered sequence of unitary gates from an elementary gate set, each which takes (at most) one argument:

\[U(x; \bm{\theta}) = U_N(\theta_{N}) U_{N-1}(\theta_{N-1}) \cdots U_i(\theta_i) \cdots U_1(\theta_1) U_0(x).\]

Note

For convenience, we have used the input \(x\) as the argument for gate \(U_0\) and the parameters \(\bm{\theta}\) for the remaining gates. This is not required. Inputs and parameters can be arbitrarily assigned to different gates.

Each of these gates takes the form \(U_{j}(\gamma_j)=\exp{(i\gamma_j H_j)}\) where \(H_j\) is a Hermitian operator which generates the gate and \(\gamma_j\) is the gate parameter. We have also suppressed the subsystems that these gates have been applied to, since it doesn’t affect the gradient formula.

Acting on a single one-parameter gate, the gradient formula is straightforward:

\[\nabla_{\gamma} U(\gamma) = \nabla_\gamma\exp{(i\gamma H)} = H\exp{(i\gamma H)} = HU(\gamma).\]

Since the equations governing quantum circuits are linear, we can pass the gradient through all the unitaries which don’t use the parameter \(\theta_i\):

\[\nabla_{\theta_i}U(x;\bm{\theta}) = U_N(\theta_{N}) U_{N-1}(\theta_{N-1}) \cdots \left[ \nabla_{\theta_i} U_i(\theta_i) \right] \cdots U_1(\theta_1) U_0(x).\]

Note: It might also be useful to have a quantum device that can evaluate standalone gradients, e.g., for calculating forces in quantum chemistry
